intro: Alcea tabrisiana, commonly known as the Persian hollyhock, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its tall, spindly stems and large, showy flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid environments. Its flowers are usually pink or red, with five petals and a prominent central pistil. Alcea tabrisiana is often cultivated for its ornamental value and can thrive in gardens with well-drained soil.
